skill.name: Global Error Handling
skill.description: Implement user-friendly error handling with specific exception types, centralized error handling, graceful degradation, and proper resource cleanup. Use this skill when implementing error handling in controllers, services, or API endpoints, when creating custom exception classes, when writing try-catch blocks, when handling external service failures, when implementing retry strategies, when displaying error messages to users, when cleaning up resources in finally blocks, or when implementing fail-fast validation and error detection.

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation and best practice guidelines for error handling. No executable code, network calls, or file system access detected. The skill promotes security best practices including proper error message sanitization and resource cleanup.

content.user_title: Implement Secure Error Handling in Laravel
content.value_statement: Poor error handling exposes sensitive data and creates security vulnerabilities. This skill ensures your Laravel applications handle errors securely with proper validation, user-friendly messages, and resource cleanup.
actual_capabilities: Provides secure error handling patterns for Laravel applications
Guides creation of custom exception classes with proper typing
Ensures user-friendly error messages without exposing technical details
Implements proper resource cleanup in finally blocks
Handles external service failures with retry strategies
limitations: Focuses on backend error handling only
Does not include frontend error display logic
Assumes familiarity with PHP exception handling

use_cases.title: Secure API Error Responses
use_cases.description: Implement proper error handling in REST APIs that returns safe, informative messages to clients without exposing internal system details.

use_cases.title: Centralized Error Logging
use_cases.description: Set up centralized error handling that logs appropriately while protecting sensitive user data and system information.

use_cases.title: Graceful Service Degradation
use_cases.description: Handle external service failures gracefully with retry mechanisms and fallback strategies for critical application features.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Error Handler
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a custom exception class for handling payment failures in a Laravel e-commerce application. Include proper type hints and a user-friendly message.

prompt_templates.title: API Error Response
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement error handling for a Laravel API endpoint that validates user input and returns appropriate HTTP status codes with safe error messages.

prompt_templates.title: Retry Strategy
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a retry mechanism with exponential backoff for handling transient failures when calling an external payment gateway API.

prompt_templates.title: Resource Cleanup
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement proper error handling with resource cleanup for a file upload feature that processes images and stores them in cloud storage.

output_examples.input: Create error handling for a user registration API that validates email uniqueness
output: Creates a Form Request class with validation rules
Implements unique email validation with custom error messages
Returns 422 status code with user-friendly validation errors
Logs validation failures without exposing sensitive data

best_practices: Always use specific exception types instead of generic Exception class
Implement proper resource cleanup in finally blocks to prevent leaks
Log errors appropriately while protecting sensitive user information
Handle errors at appropriate boundaries (controllers, API layers)
anti_patterns: Never expose technical error details or stack traces to end users
Avoid scattering try-catch blocks throughout business logic
Don't ignore exceptions with empty catch blocks
Never log sensitive data like passwords or credit card numbers

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with Laravel 11 and 12?
faq.answer: Yes, the error handling patterns work with all modern Laravel versions including 11 and 12.

faq.question: Does this handle frontend error display?
faq.answer: No, this focuses on backend error handling. Frontend display logic should be implemented separately.

faq.question: Can I use this with Inertia.js applications?
faq.answer: Yes, the error handling patterns work well with Inertia.js for seamless error propagation.

faq.question: How does this protect against information disclosure?
faq.answer: It ensures technical details are never exposed to users, returning safe, generic error messages instead.

faq.question: What about error monitoring and alerting?
faq.answer: The skill focuses on error handling patterns. Integrate with services like Sentry or Bugsnag for monitoring.

faq.question: Does this include retry logic for failed operations?
faq.answer: Yes, it provides guidance on implementing retry strategies with exponential backoff for external services.
